topics.definition: The allocation of money or capital into assets with the expectation of generating income or profit in the future.
key_points: Investment helps in wealth creation and meeting long-term financial goals.
Different investment options carry different levels of risk and return.
Diversification reduces risk by spreading investments across different assets.
processes: Identify financial goals and risk tolerance.
Research different investment options.
Allocate funds across chosen investments.
Monitor and review investments periodically.
examples: Direct equity: buying shares of companies.
Mutual funds: pooling money with other investors for professionally managed portfolios.
Fixed deposits: lending money to banks for fixed interest.
Bonds: lending to governments or companies for fixed returns.
Real estate: buying property for rental income or capital appreciation.
Gold: purchasing gold as a traditional safe-haven asset.
facts: Direct equity carries higher risk but potential for higher returns.
Fixed deposits offer guaranteed returns with low risk.
Mutual funds provide diversification and professional management.

topics.topic_name: Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI)
topics.definition: The statutory body established to regulate, promote, and ensure orderly growth of the insurance industry in India.
key_points: Protects policyholders' interests.
Registers and regulates insurance companies and intermediaries.
Ensures insurance coverage reaches rural and vulnerable sections.
Promotes fair competition and consumer choice.
processes: IRDAI sets rules for insurance companies.
Monitors financial health and market conduct of insurers.
Handles policyholder grievances through integrated systems.
Promotes insurance penetration and awareness.
examples: Licensing new insurance companies.
Setting norms for insurance products and premiums.
Operating grievance redressal through toll-free number 155255.
Ensuring solvency margins are maintained by insurers.
facts: Established under IRDAI Act, 1999.
Comprises a chairman, five full-time, and four part-time members.
Insurance penetration in India was 3.96% as of 2013.
Over 52 insurance companies were operating in India as of March 2014.

topics.definition: Funds required for starting, operating, and expanding a business, obtained from various internal and external sources.
key_points: Classified by period: short-term, medium-term, long-term.
Classified by ownership: owner’s funds and borrowed funds.
Classified by source: internal and external.
processes: Assess financial needs of the business.
Choose appropriate source based on cost, duration, and control.
Raise funds through equity, loans, or internal accruals.
Repay or service the funds as per terms.
examples: Equity shares: ownership capital raised from public.
Preference shares: fixed dividend with priority over equity.
Debentures: long-term loans from investors.
Retained earnings: profits reinvested in business.
Trade credit: buying now and paying later to suppliers.
Bank loans: term loans, cash credit, overdraft.
facts: Equity shareholders are owners of the company.
Debenture holders are creditors, not owners.
Trade credit is a common short-term financing source.
Retained earnings are the cheapest source of finance.

topics.definition: PAN (Permanent Account Number) is a unique identifier for taxpayers; Aadhaar is a 12-digit unique identity number for residents of India.
key_points: PAN is mandatory for financial transactions above specified limits.
Aadhaar serves as proof of identity and address.
Both are used for KYC (Know Your Customer) in financial services.
Aadhaar facilitates direct benefit transfers and financial inclusion.
processes: Apply online or through authorized centers.
Submit proof of identity, address, and photographs.
Receive unique number after verification.
Link with bank accounts and other services as required.
examples: PAN required for opening bank accounts, buying property, or investing.
Aadhaar used for opening bank accounts, getting SIM cards, and availing subsidies.
Quoting PAN for deposits above ₹50,000 or foreign travel above ₹25,000.
facts: PAN is a 10-digit alphanumeric number issued by Income Tax Department.
Aadhaar is issued by UIDAI (Unique Identification Authority of India).
Having more than one PAN is illegal.
Aadhaar is voluntary, not mandatory for all services.

topics.definition: Mechanisms available to policyholders to resolve complaints against insurance companies or intermediaries.
key_points: First approach the insurer's Grievance Redressal Officer.
If unresolved within 15 days, escalate to IRDAI.
IRDAI facilitates resolution but does not adjudicate.
Multiple channels: call center, email, online portal, post.
processes: File written complaint with insurer with supporting documents.
Insurer must resolve within 15 days.
If unsatisfied, register complaint with IRDAI via IGMS.
IRDAI follows up with insurer for resolution.
examples: Complaint about delay in claim settlement.
Dispute over policy terms or premium.
Mis-selling by insurance agent.
Unauthorized charges or policy changes.
facts: IRDAI toll-free number: 155255.
IGMS: Integrated Grievance Management System.
IRDAI (Protection of Policyholders’ Interests) Regulations, 2002 govern the process.
IRDAI monitors but does not investigate individual complaints.

topics.definition: Credit cards allow borrowing money up to a limit for purchases; debit cards allow spending money directly from bank accounts.
key_points: Credit cards involve borrowing with interest if not repaid fully.
Debit cards deduct funds immediately from linked account.
Both offer convenience and security over cash.
Credit cards offer rewards, but can lead to debt if misused.
processes: Apply to bank with income and credit history proof.
Receive card with credit limit (credit card) or linked to account (debit card).
Use for purchases online/offline by entering PIN/OTP.
Repay credit card bill by due date to avoid interest.
examples: Credit card: buy now, pay later with interest on outstanding.
Debit card: withdraw cash from ATM or pay at merchant outlets.
Online shopping using card details and CVV.
Credit card statement shows transactions, due amount, minimum due, and due date.
facts: Credit cards have high interest rates (often 24–36% p.a.).
Debit cards do not allow spending beyond account balance.
CVV (Card Verification Value) is a 3-digit security code.
Lost/stolen cards should be blocked immediately to prevent fraud.

topics.definition: Risk is uncertainty of loss; insurance is a mechanism to transfer financial impact of risk to an insurer in exchange for premium.
key_points: Insurance works on pooling of risks and law of large numbers.
Premiums are calculated based on probability and severity of loss.
Insurance provides financial security and peace of mind.
Cannot prevent risk, but compensates financial loss.
processes: Identify risks to life, health, property, etc.
Choose suitable insurance policy.
Pay premium regularly.
File claim with documents when loss occurs.
Insurer assesses and pays claim if valid.
examples: Life insurance pays nominee on death of insured.
Health insurance covers hospitalization costs.
Car insurance pays for accident repairs or theft.
Home insurance covers damage from fire, natural disasters.
facts: Insurance penetration in India is low compared to global average.
Group insurance is cheaper than individual policies.
Peril is the event causing loss (e.g., fire, accident).
Policyholder is the person who owns the insurance policy.

topics.definition: The central bank of India, responsible for monetary policy, currency issue, banking regulation, and financial stability.
key_points: Issuer of currency (except ₹1 notes and coins).
Banker to government and banks.
Regulator of banking and payment systems.
Controller of credit and inflation through monetary policy.
processes: Formulates and implements monetary policy.
Supervises banks for compliance and stability.
Manages foreign exchange reserves.
Acts as lender of last resort to banks.
examples: RBI increases repo rate to control inflation.
Sets CRR and SLR for banks.
Withdraws old currency notes from circulation.
Regulates digital payments like UPI, NEFT, RTGS.
facts: Established on April 1, 1935; nationalized in 1949.
Headed by a Governor appointed by Government of India.
Monetary Policy Committee decides interest rates.
RBI ensures financial inclusion through schemes like PMJDY.

topics.definition: Planning of income and expenses over a period to ensure financial stability, savings, and goal achievement.
key_points: Helps track income, expenses, and savings.
Differentiates between needs and wants.
Enables prioritization of spending and goal-setting.
Prevents overspending and debt accumulation.
processes: List all sources of income.
Categorize expenses: fixed, variable, discretionary.
Allocate funds for savings and investments.
Monitor actual spending against budget and adjust.
examples: Monthly household budget covering rent, food, utilities, education, entertainment.
Personal budget for student’s pocket money.
Business budget for revenues, costs, and profits.
Event budget for wedding or travel.
facts: Budget should be realistic and flexible.
Emergency fund should be part of budget.
Budgeting tools: spreadsheets, apps, envelopes system.
Review budget regularly to stay on track.

topics.definition: Borrowed funds provided by banks or financial institutions for specific purposes, to be repaid with interest.
key_points: Loans can be secured (against collateral) or unsecured.
Interest rates vary based on type, tenure, and borrower profile.
Repayment is through EMIs (Equated Monthly Installments).
Default affects credit score and may lead to asset seizure.
processes: Apply with loan application form and documents.
Bank checks credit history via CIBIL score.
Sanction and disbursement after verification.
Repay through EMIs over loan tenure.
examples: Home loan: for buying/constructing house.
Personal loan: for weddings, travel, medical needs.
Education loan: for studies in India/abroad.
Vehicle loan: for car, bike, commercial vehicle.
Gold loan: against gold ornaments.
Agricultural loan: for crops, equipment, irrigation.
facts: CIBIL score ranges from 300 to 900; higher is better.
Overdraft allows withdrawing more than account balance up to limit.
Collateral is asset pledged against loan (e.g., property, gold).
Loan eligibility depends on income, age, employment, and credit history.

topics.definition: A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over time, reducing purchasing power.
key_points: Measured by indices: WPI (Wholesale Price Index) and CPI (Consumer Price Index).
Causes: demand-pull, cost-push, supply shocks.
Effects: reduces real income, erodes savings, impacts fixed-income groups.
Controlled by monetary policy (RBI) and fiscal policy (government).
processes: RBI monitors inflation data.
Uses tools like repo rate, CRR, SLR to control money supply.
Government adjusts taxes and spending to manage demand.
Supply-side measures: improve production, reduce bottlenecks.
examples: Demand-pull inflation: too much money chasing too few goods.
Cost-push inflation: rise in oil prices increasing transport costs.
Supply shock: crop failure raising food prices.
Hyperinflation: extremely high and accelerating inflation (rare).
facts: Inflation target in India: 4% with ±2% tolerance.
CPI includes food, fuel, housing, clothing, etc.
Deflation is fall in general price level, can harm economy.
Inflation indexed bonds protect investors from inflation.
